Gloria is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase more fish to sell. This will be the 12th loan taken out by Gloria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is married and has three children. Her husband is a mason. Aba smokes fish for sale at Elmina, which she has done for five years. Aba assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Aba will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to smoke for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more fresh fish to smoke for sale.

loans.name: Prudence

texts.en:
Prudence is a married woman with five children, two of whom attend school while three have graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a food vending business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of transportation in her business. She dreams of establishing a restaurant in the future. 

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase furniture seats for her restaurant, bundles of wheat flour and maize flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase furniture seats for her restaurant, bundles of wheat flour and maize flour.

loans.name: Sabir

texts.en:
Sabir has always been a hard-working man who has made sure from his young age that his family never goes without their daily bread. He is married and has two children. He has had a grocery store for seven years where he sells different kinds of foodstuffs such as sweets, soft drinks, juices, and other items. Today, he needs to buy additional foodstuffs to increase the range of goods he sells. 

With this purpose in mind, he is requesting a loan of 1,000 AZN. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: to purchase more food products to sell

loans.name: Manuna Group

texts.en:
Mamie is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. She is 40 years old and was born in Pujehun town. Mamie is married and has three children. For many years now, she has been selling fish in the market. Mamie will use her share of the loan (500,000 leones) to expand her business; she will buy a large quantity of fish to add to her current stock.  

This is the first loan that Mamie and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of fish to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Manuel Antonio

texts.es:
Manuel, es motorista de un bus, también es agricultor, vive con su esposa y tienen un hijo de 6 años de edad, tiene 5 años de ser motorista y al cultivo agrícola se dedica desde hace 10 años, de estas ocupaciones ha logrado mantener a su familia.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para la compra de fertilizantes para el cultivo, esta compra le ayudara para tener los insumos agrícolas que fortalezcan y produzcan buenos frutos en la siembra.
Para Manuel su propósito es sacar a su hijo adelante, velar por las necesidades de el, por esta razón se esfuerza diariamente para conseguir los ingresos necesarios.
texts.en:
Manuel drives a bus. He is also a farmer. He lives with his wife and they have one child that is 6 months old. He has been working as a driver for the past five years. He has been growing crops for the past ten years. In this way he can support his family.
Actually, he is requesting this loan in order to buy fertilizer for his crops. This loan will help him buy the agricultural products her needs to support and produce good fruit at harvest time. 
Manuel wishes to help his son be successful. He struggles to provide for his necessities. This is why he makes a good effort everyday to obtain the necessary income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for his crops.

loans.name: Armie

texts.en:
Armie is 40 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. 

Armie has a shop that sells snacks like rice & cassava cakes. She has had this business for 4 years. She requested a loan fof PHP 8,000 to buy raw ingredients needed for making snacks.

Armie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Armie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for making snacks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to plant passion fruit

loans.name: Amerta Kencana Group

texts.en: The Amerta Kencana group is a group consisting of 10 members who live in one village and have the same type of business. They raise pigs. This is their second loan.  Ni Putu, the head of the group, is taking a loan of Rp 1,500,000 to buy four local species piglets. Right now, she is just keeping piglets, but Ni Putu has plans to buy sows and become a piglet seller. To raise capital, she will save from the sale of her pigs during this period. Currently, the piglets are very expensive (Rp  400,000) because it is difficult to find them. That's because people rarely maintain piglets. It was seen as a good attempt by Ni Putu. She hopes the plan and her efforts will be successful with financial support and guidance from MUK.

loans.use: To buy four piglets

loans.name: Rajab

texts.ru: Ражаб проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 47 лет. Женат. Имеет четверых детей. Его жена занимается домашним хозяйством. Сам Ражаб предоставляет услугу, такси. Этим видом деятельности он занимается 20 лет. Кроме того в свободное время он занимается животноводством. Кредит берет для приобретения баллонов и закупа теленка.
texts.en: Rajab lives in the Yavan district.  He is 47 years old, married and has four children.  His wife is involved in household work.  Rajab provides a taxi service.  He has been involved in this business for 20 years.  Besides this, he is involved in animal husbandry in his spare time.  Rajab is requesting this loan to buy containers and a calf.

loans.use: to buy containers and a calf

loans.name: Edwin

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “BANCO DEL DESARROLLO”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr. Edwin; el tiene 34 años de edad y es soltero; El socio alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de restaurant y también tiene un agencia de viajes, el restaurant lo administra su pareja y juntos sacan adelante sus negocios, el socio quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de restaurant y negocio de agencia de viajes. El  socio solicita el préstamo para comprar productos para cocinar como arroz, carne, pollo y verduras y para implementar la agencia de viajes.

 El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Edwin belongs to the communal bank “BANCO DEL DESARROLLO” (Development Bank).  The bank is located in Cuzco, located in the province and state of the same name. 

Edwin is 34 years old and single.  He has two businesses, a restaurant and a travel agency.  His wife runs their restaurant and they both help their businesses to get ahead.  Edwin would like to expand and improve his restaurant and travel agency.  He is requesting a loan to purchase food items to cook such as rice, meat, chicken and vegetables, and to set up the travel agency. 

He is happy to receive the loan and promises to make his payments on time.

loans.use: to purchase food to cook such as rice, meat, chicken and vegetables, and to set up a travel agency.

loans.name: Walter Enrique

texts.es:
Walter, esta solicitando un préstamo, lo necesita para comprar más mercadería para surtir su negocio y comprar más ropa: vestidos, pantalones, camisas, blusas y de esa forma incrementara sus ganancias porque tendrá más variedad para ofrecerles a sus clientes.
El prestamo anterior le ayudo para mantener el negocio surtido, y gracias a las buenas ventas, cancelo totalmente el prestamo y esta decidiendose por un nuevo prestamo.
El sueño de Walter   es tener una mejor calidad de vida y vender mas ya que su familia dependen de él y darles lo necesario.
texts.en:
Walter requests a loan to purchase more merchandise to add inventory to his business. He plans on buying more clothing, such as: dresses, pants, shirts, and blouses. This will increase his profits because he will have a wider variety of items to offer his clients.

The previous loan helped him maintain an inventory for his business and through the good sales volume he was able to cancel the loan completely. He has decided on taking out a new loan.

Walter's dream is to have a better quality of life and to increase his sales. His family depends on him to provide them with what they need.

loans.use: to purchase dresses, paints, shirts, and blouses for his business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary operates a food joint (a place where people come to eat varieties of food cooked) at Takoradi, which she has done for 6 years. She sells foods such as fufu, banku, konkonte and others. Her husband is a driver. Mary uses her income to support her husband to pay utility bills.  Mary will use the loan to purchase food items to cook and sell.

loans.use: to purchase food items to cook and sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 23 year old, a widow, and has one child who is not in school.  She has had a business of selling fish in Yei, south Sudan, for three years.
Mary requested this loan through BRAC south Sudan to purchase fish.  She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to build a house in future.

loans.use: to purchase fish for sale.

loans.name: Salve

texts.en:
Salve, 54, is a single parent living in Manila, Philippines. She and her children manage their own household while operating their business. Salve works hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses.

Salve operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil or an egg. Salve earns an income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in daily sales.

To help her continue operations of her business, Salve is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan, which she will use to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Salve hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Eoun

texts.en: Eoun, 60, resides in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She sells fried chickens and mangoes. The family is also assisted by her two children, currently employed at the garment factory. Eoun is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Kimya Plus Group

texts.en:
Kimya Plus is a Community Bank of 12 owners of small businesses chaired by Nzenza. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva through the MFI HOPE DRCongo to grow their businesses.
Nzenza 39, single, is an itinerant photographer in his area located in the west of Kinshasa. He is well known and has many customers throughout the city of Kinshasa. He became a microentrepreneur in 1996. He has already received seven loans from Kiva through Microfinance Institution HOPE DRC and fully repaid them. He intends to use the next loan to purchase some camera accessories and photo frames to resell in order to reinforce his working capital. Currently, he earns a profit of US$60 per week. Nzenza is the father of a nine-year-old son who attends school.

loans.use: to purchase some camera accessories and photo frames to resell in order to reinforce his working capital

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is married and has three children. She is 29 years old and lives in Tonggo, Tudela.

Gina is a farmer and grows vegetable crops to earn a living. Gina has been doing this for 10 years. 

Gina has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional fertilizer for planting crops.

Gina has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future, she hopes to expand the business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fertilizer for planting crops.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase corn, beans, toilet paper, oil, and sweets.

loans.name: Olivia Mayela

texts.es:
Olivia tiene 53 años es madre soltera , muy humilde y con esa humildad ha sacado adelante a su 4 hijos los cuales se sienten muy orgullosos de ella porque a pesar de los contratiempos ella siempre los ha apoyado, ella Olivia siempre le ha gustado trabajar, primero vendía frutas a las afueras del mercado de su barrio pero fue desalojada, por ello decidió poner otro negocio, al cual se dedica actualmente a la venta de ropa interior por el mercado de su barrio también, pero recorriéndolo en busca de clientes, ella en un día puede ganar s/. 60 pero en un día muy  bueno puede ganar hasta S/. 120, ella cree que le va bien en su negocio porque es muy carismática y atenta con los clientes, ella nos comenta que mientras tenga salud ella seguirá trabajando no importa que llegue a tener 100 años, mientras se sienta joven.

Olivia está muy pero muy agradecida con los prestatarios Kiva ya que gracias al apoyo que le han brindado ella podrá comprar mas mercadería para la temporada de verano como sombrillas, gorros, bikinis y accesorios para la temporada, así ella tendrá mas variedad de productos para ofrecer a sus clientes y con ello tendrá mas ingresos con lo que mejorara su calidad de vida así como también seguir ahorrando para cumplir su gran sueño:” Terminar de comprar los muebles y artefactos para su hogar y vivir mucho mejor”
texts.en:
Olivia is 53 years old and a single mother. She is very humble, and this has gotten her four children ahead in life. They are very proud of her because in spite of the setbacks, she has always supported them. 

Olivia has always liked to work. First she sold fruit at the outskirts of her neighborhood market, but she was vacated. Therefore she decided to open a new business, where she now sells underwear at her neighborhood market, and she also travels in search of customers. In a day she can earn S/. 60, or up to S/. 120 on a really good day. She believes that her business is doing well because she's very charismatic and attentive to her customers. Olivia tells us that as long as she has her health, she will continue working as long as she feels young, even if she reaches 100 years. 

Olivia is so very grateful to the Kiva lenders, because thanks to the help they've offered she will be able to buy more merchandise for the summer season, like umbrellas, caps, bikinis, and accessories for the season. This way she'll have more variety in her products to offer her clients, and in turn Olivia will have a greater income with which to improve her quality of life. She will continue to save to reach her great dream: "to finish buying furniture and appliances for her home and to live much better."

loans.use: to buy merchandise for the summer (umbrellas, caps, bikinis).

loans.name: Delfín Manuel

texts.es: El cliente reside en Libertad.  Empezó con la fabricación de muebles para luego emprender en su bazar propio, en donde vende libros, artículos varios y de tienda.  Trabaja todo el día junto con su sobrino que le ayuda en esta actividad.  No es casada y por el momento no tiene hijos.  Desea a futuro que su negocio siga surgiendo y dotarlo de más mercadería.  Ahora requiere el préstamo para la compra de artículos como libros y ropa.
texts.en:
This borrower resides in Libertad. He started out making furniture, but later he opened his own bazaar where he sells books and various other types of merchandise. He works every day at his business with the help of his nephew. The borrower is not married and currently has no children. In the future, he wants his business to keep growing and to stock it with more merchandise.

For now, he is requesting a loan in order to buy merchandise, such as books and clothing.

loans.use: to buy books, clothing, and various other merchandise to sell in his bazaar.

loans.name: Muhamed

texts.en: Muhamed H. H. lives in Kardjali and is 40 years old. He is married and his son is 19 years old. Muhamed has extremely varied professional experience. Firs he was a cutter in a press house inn the town, then he worked as a mechanic in a tobacco factory. Four years he spent in Turkey where he was a carpenter and another two years in The Netherlands as a butcher in a meat-producing factory. When in 2004 he came back to Bulgaria he decided to start farming business. He started his business with two cows and now 3 years later he breeds 30 cows. Now Muhamed wants to buy three more cows and needs $2 000.

loans.use: To buy three more cows

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Mrs. Paulina U. is a trader who sells diesel and kerosene. She is happily married with four (4) children. She is from a semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She hopes to use the loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more diesel and kerosene for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more stocks of used clothes for her business expansion

loans.name: Silvia Mirta

texts.en:
Silvia is 47 years old and lives in Juliaca with her 8 year-old daughter and her husband. Two years ago she rented a storefront on the road leading out of Juliaca to Cusco. She began selling limited merchandise such as candy, cookies, and sodas. With a $500 loan, she expanded her merchandise to include cooking ingredients.

She is now requesting a loan of $625 so that she can continue to expand her merchandise. She says she has a competitive advantage over other stores in the area because she buys all her products in bulk from legitimate companies in Juliaca and therefore has higher quality products than most of her competitors who buy from informal markets.

loans.use: Increase the quality and variety of her merchandise.

loans.name: Lizbeth

texts.es:
Lizbeth is a very industrious woman. She is very dedicated to her work and she enjoys sales. She is divorced and has 2 kids who are 12 and 6 years old, both of whom study. She started her business because she realized her capacity as a saleswoman and she loved doing it. She also needed to support her kids. She started off selling sweets and TupperWare products, but after a while she started to sell clothes too. This went very well for her so she decided to stick to it, and little by little her business has grown.

Lizbeth would like a loan of $475 to buy fall-winter clothes so that she will have many attractive products for her clients. She will repay this loan in 4 months. Her and her kids thank you for the support that you are able to offer them as they know that the business can grow with your cooperation.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Lizbeth se considera una mujer muy emprendedora, dedicada a su trabajo y con un gusto muy grande por las ventas, ella esta divorciada y tiene dos hijos de 12 y 6 años de edad respectivamente, ambos estudiantes. Ella empezó con su negocio por que se dio cuenta de su potencial como vendedora y le encantaba hacerlo, así que por ello y por la necesidad de mantener a sus hijos decidió a vender en un inicio dulces y productos Tupper Ware, pero paso el tiempo y empezó a vender ropa y eso le ha funcionado mucho mejor y hasta ahora se dedica a ello, creciendo poco a poco con su negocio.

Lizbeth esta solicitando un préstamo por la cantidad de US $ 475 para comprar ropa de temporada otoño-invierno y así tener productos atractivos para sus clientes y poder ampliar su cartera de clientes, ofreciendo pagar el préstamo en 4 meses, ella y sus hijos te agradecen el apoyo que les brindas y por que sabe que podrá crecer con su negocio gracias a tu colaboración.

loans.use: To buy merchandise/Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Ena

texts.es:
Ena is a hard-working mother that got into the world of natural medicine as a result of the difficult illness from which her youngest child suffers, diabetes. She began her voyage by attending training talks, given by respected professionals, about the goodness of specific products native to their countries, capable of returning the health and well-being of those who consume them appropriately. Absorbed with a lot of information, and with the little savings that she had, she decided to aquire specific products to provide to the general public. In the beginning and because of the lack of knowledge of these natural products, she had a certain difficulty; however, gradually, the sales from these products became her primary source of income.

In this way and thanks to her hard work, she is contributing to the improvement of the quality of life of her humble home. Because of the great acceptance (of the products) and because her clientele is constantly growing, she has an urgent need to buy more products. To carry out the fulfillment her goals, she's asking for a loan of $425, which she will repay in 6 months, which will permit her to lay the foundation of her business. Through your help, we will make it possible to fulfill this desire.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

Ena, es una diligente madre que incursionó en el mundo de la medicina natural a raíz de la delicada enfermedad que padece el menor de sus hijos, diabetes. Inició su travesía asistiendo a las charlas de capacitación que otorgaban profesionales respecto a las bondades de determinado productos oriundos de su país, capaces de devolverle la salud y bienestar a quién las consume adecuadamente.Empapada de mucha información, con los pequeños ahorros que tenia decidió adquirir determinados productos para ofrecerlos al público en general, a principio y debido a la poca difusión de estos preparados naturales tuvo cierta dificultad; sin embargo paulatinamente se fue convirtiendo en su principal fuente de ingresos. De esta manera y gracias a su desempeño contribuye a incrementar el nivel de vida de su humilde hogar.Por la gran aceptación y la cartera de clientes en constante crecimiento, se encuentra en la apremiante necesidad de comprar más productos. Para llevar a cabo el cumplimiento de sus metas esta solicitando 425 dólares en calidad de préstamo con un periodo de devolución de seis meses, que le permitirá la cimentación de su negocio.A través de vuestro apoyo posibilitaremos el cumplimiento de este anhelo.

loans.use: The purchase of Natural Products to increase her sales.

loans.name: Wassila

texts.en: Wassila is 35 years old. She lives and works in the region of Nabatieh, in the south of Lebanon. Wassila can be described as a hard worker since she sells pesticides and has also opened a small bakery. She needs a loan of $300 to buy the required merchandise for both her businesses.

loans.use: Wassila would like to buy the required merchandise for her bakery.

loans.name: Grace's Tujikomboe Group

texts.en:
Grace, 30, is married and has 2 children (ages 10 and 7). She runs a clothing business, which she began in 2005. Every day, she sells from 10 am to 5 pm, and now she can make a monthly profit of about $70 from this business.

Grace hopes for a loan to buy more clothing for resale. She will share this loan with Amina, a member of her loan group. Amina is a food vendor and lives in the same neighborhood as Grace.

loans.use: To buy clothing stock

loans.name: Bukaye B East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Azena N.. She is currently in the business of selling silver fish and also has a grocery store. She is requesting a loan to add more stock in her shop. Azena is 32 years old and is married. Her husband has a carpentry workshop. She has 4 children ranging from age 4 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Azena makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits, and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay back the loan and also pay school fees for the children. Azena has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy more items for her stall, and the loan was paid back on time.

Azena is joined in her small group by Lukiya N., Sumaya M., Rose N., and Fatina B.. Lukiya N. has a retail shop business and wants to purchase more shop items. Sumaya M. is currently operating a business in fruit and vegetable selling and wants a loan to purchase more fruits for sale. Rose N. operates a grocery business and wants to boost business. Fatina B. is currently in the business of selling produce and bagiya and is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.use: To add in fish business

loans.name: Elnara

texts.en: Elnara was born in 1978. She is single, and lives in the town of Khachmaz. Elnara has been in the retail business for 2 years.  She needs a loan of $1200 to buy clothes and electrical goods.

loans.use: to buy clothes, electrical goods

loans.name: Enriqueta

texts.es:
Ms. Enriqueta V. started her cosmetics business 14 years ago. She started out helping a friend to sell, and that is how she would generate the extra income that helped her financially with the household expenses. Upon realizing that this activity was lucrative, she decided to work directly for those cosmetics companies with the aim of earning more income. Today, her business has prospered, and she has been able to cover her financial expenses.

She is currently requesting a loan of $400.00 US for 6 months in order to purchase merchandise at wholesale prices, thus giving her customers better service. She fully trusts that she will obtain that loan with Kiva’s support.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Ella inicio su negocio de Venta de cosméticos hace 14 años, primero ayudándole a una amiga a vender y así recibía algo de ingresos extras, que le ayudaba económicamente con los gastos de su hogar. Al darse cuenta que le estaba yendo bien decidió hacer el trato directamente con las líneas de cosméticos, esto con la finalidad de obtener mas ganancias, hoy en día le ha ido muy bien y ha podido salir adelante con los gastos económicos.

Ahora solicita de un crédito de US $400 a 6 meses, para la compra de mercancía a precio de mayoreo, y así dar mejor servicio a sus clientes, ella confía plenamente que con el apoyo de Kiva obtendrá su crédito.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Mrs. Long N., 61, is a widow with three children, two sons and one daughter. One of her sons is married and lives outside the family home. Her other son one runs a motor taxi, and her daughter weaves silk at home. The family lives on an Island on the Mekong River about 15 km from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Long has been a weaver for 45 years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village, who will take it to sell in Phnom Penh. She has two looms in the family; one is for her daughter and other is her own. Though she is in her early 60s, she is still strong enough to work.

She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase silk materials for weaving and buy a motorbike to replace the old one for her son's motor taxi.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and buy a motorbike

loans.name: Talosaga

texts.en:
Talosaga V., 42, is married with 5 children. She has many years' experience in the taro/banana business. She sells to the village community and Fugalei market 3 days per week.

Talosaga has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (about US$ 104). SPBD loans are Talosaga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

She will spend all this first loan on her business only. Her husband is the main boss of the project; he is the one that does planning for maintaining their plantation.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, insect sprayer, bush knife, shovel

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara M., 58, is married with 5 children and lives at Nuusuatia, Samoa. She and her husband have been growing taro for 3 years. She sells her crop to the villagers and the general public 2 days per week.

This is Tamara's first loan with SPBD, which she will use to purchase equipment for her taro plantation. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (US$208). SPBD loans are Tamara’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase to fund chemicals,weedkiller,knife,empty gallon.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet, a 51-year-old trader, is married with five children. Three of her children have completed senior high school. She is a very resourceful wife and mother whose hard effort brings livelihood to the family. Janet supports her husband in providing for the household through the sale of used clothing and shoes. There is a very big market in Ghana for used clothing, as brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore selling of used clothing has created opportunity for many women. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing and shoes to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her save for her children's future and also to rent a store in which to trade. She is member of the group called Gold. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy increased bales of used clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Esther

texts.fr: A. Esther est âgé de 28 ans et pharmacienne de profession. Elle est  mariée et mère de deux enfants. Mme Esther tient un dépôt de pharmacie et de produits esthétiques à Kpalimé une ville située au sud-ouest du Togo à 120 Km de Lomé la capitale Togolaise. Par cette chance de Kiva ,et ce premier crédit de FECECAV, elle souhaite faire des approvisionnements en produits génériques et de beauté afin de dégager suffisamment de profits ; ce faisant ainsi elle pourra gagner la confiance de soi et prendre en partie les charges du ménage.
texts.en:
Mrs. Esther A., 28, is a pharmacist by profession. She is married and the mother of two children. Esther runs a shop selling pharmaceuticals and beauty products in Kpalimé, a town situated in the southwest of Togo, 120 km from Lomé, the capital of Togo.

With the chance offered by Kiva and this first loan though FECECAV, she hopes to stock up on generic products and cosmetics in order to make sufficient profit from her shop. This will allow her to gain self-confidence and help support the family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of generic pharmaceuticals and cosmetics for re-sale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace O. lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 44 years old, married and has 5 children.

Grace sells yams which she buys from the northern part of the country  The demand for her yams is high from now until the end of the year. Therefore Grace needs a loan in the amount of $1200 to buy more yams to meet this demand.

She says thank you to all who make this loan possible, especially Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more yams to sell

loans.name: Violeta

texts.es: Violeta tiene 26 años, es soltera, vive en casa de sus padres, quienes la apoyan en todo. La muy empeñosa Violeta se dedica a la venta de comida en su pequeño local ubicado en su casa, desde hace 8 años atrás. Comienza el día preparando los desayunos que ofrecerá, atendiendo a los clientes hasta la hora de almuerzo, para de nuevo abrir aproximadamente a las 5 o 6 de la tarde, para la venta salchipapas (papas fritas con salchicha) y salchipollo (papas fritas con pollo), tiene gran cantidad de clientela que frecuenta su local, siendo la venta muy buena. Violeta trabaja para poder ser independiente y crearse un futuro lleno de esperanzas y oportunidades. Con el dinero del préstamo comprará algunas ollas y cucharones que le hacen falta, además de ingredientes para preparar sus delicias.  En el futuro, a Violeta le gustaría tener un gran restaurante.
texts.en:
Violeta is 26 years old, is single, and lives in her parent’s house. Her parents are supportive of her in all things. The very determined Violeta has been selling food from her small restaurant, located in her house, for the past eight years. She begins her day preparing the breakfasts that she will offer, tending to the customers until lunch-time, and then opening again at 5 or 6 in the evening to sell salchipapas (fried potatoes with sausage) and salchipollo (fried potatoes with chicken). She has a large number of customers at her restaurant and sales are very good. Violeta is working so that she can be independent and create for herself a future full of hopes and opportunities. With the money from the loan she will buy some pots and large spoons that she needs, and also the ingredients to prepare her delicious foods. In the future, Violeta would like to have a large restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking utensils and ingredients for preparing her foods.

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cécile Fifonsi D., is the mother of four children and is married to Bernard Deji, a radio and television repairman. She was born on November 28, 1972 in Porto-Novo in Ouémé County in southern Benin. Cécile distributes fabric and sells drinks. She is requesting a loan so that she may buy more inventory and be prepared for the end-of-the year rush. This will increase her income.

Alidé means “another path always exists for the most poor” in Fon, the principal tribal language of Cotonou, Benin. Benin is a small country in West Africa sandwiched between Togo and Nigeria. GDP per capita stands at $1,500 and poverty is endemic to the capital city of Cotonou. Alidé operates seven different locations in and around Cotonou to ensure that those who need help can help themselves through small loans.

loans.use: To purchase of 15 packs of drinks and 10 packages of fabric

loans.name: Jardin Group

texts.es: EL GRUPO "JARDÍN " ESTA REPRESENTADO POR LA SEÑORA MARTHA QUIEN SE DEDICA AL LA VENTA Y PRODUCCIÓN D. LECHE AL IGUAL QUE EL RESTO D. SUS COMPAÑEROS D. GRUPO, ELLOS ENTREGAN SU PRODUCCIÓN A LA PLANTA PROCESADORA D. LECHE (PIL), PERO LOS SOCIOS (AS) TAMBIÉN ELABORAN ALGUNOS D. LOS DERIVADOS D. LA LECHE PARA LA VENTA DIRECTAMENTE AL CONSUMIDOR COMO EL YOGUR CASERO, QUESILLO Y OTROS. PESE A EXISTIR COMPETENCIA EN EL MERCADO LÁCTEOS LAS SEÑORAS  LOGRAN VENDER SUS PRODUCTOS NATURALES DIRECTAMENTE EN EL MERCADO. EL DESTINO D. ESTE CRÉDITO ES PARA LA ADQUISICIÓN D. MAS VACAS LECHERAS PARA AUMENTAR SU PRODUCCIÓN Y MEJORAR SUS INGRESOS. LOS SOCIOS (AS9 YA TIENE EXPERIENCIA TRABAJANDO CON GRUPOS SOLIDARIOS POR LO QUE SABEN D. LA RESPONSABILIDAD Y LA PUNTUALIDAD QUE EXIGE UN FINANCIAMIENTO POR LO QUE SE COMPROMETEN A ADMINISTRAR BIEN SUS RECURSOS Y A CUMPLIR SUS OBLIGACIONES CON LA FUNDACIÓN.
texts.en:
The group "Jardin" is lead by Martha. She produces and sells milk, just like the rest of her partners in the group. The members hand over their raw milk to the processing plant (PIL), but they also manufacture some milk-derived products themselves, including yogurt, small cheeses, and similar foods, and sell these items directly to their customers. In spite of the competition they face from other companies in the dairy market, the ladies of the group succeeded in selling their natural products directly to customers in the market. They will use this loan to acquire more dairy cows to increase their production and improve their income. The members have previous experience working with group loans, and understand the responsibility and punctuality demanded of them by their financier. They promise to manage their resources properly and to fulfill their obligations to the foundation.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Funding for Business Operations

loans.name: Vy's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan that has four people and Mrs. S. is the leader. They live in Battambang Province, Cambodia.  S. is 39 years old and runs a small business as local money lender in her village. She normally borrows money from HKL at a low interest rate and then lends a little money to her neighbors in whom she has confidence, and charges higher interest. Her business has gone well. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver and can earn around US$3.20 per day. She has two young teenage children. 

To expand her business and increase her income, S. needs a loan to use as capital for her local lending business.

loans.use: to use as more capital for her local money lending business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce B. is a 34 year-old woman, married with two children, one of whom is currently schooling and the last born is breastfeeding. Joyce works very hard to provide for herself and her children.  She is into the sale of ladies slippers by hawking (door to door sales). With her good customer relations, Joyce believes she would make more sales if she purchases the right quality of goods demanded by her loyal customers. She says this would help her make more profit to expand her business and also finance her kid’s education. She also sells gari and fried fish at the main road of Koforidua where she currently lives. Gari is prepared from milled cassava. It has been her wish to restock her inventory with raw materials but she is constrained with adequate funds to make business progress.  Joyce again believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support her husband to provide food and finance her children education.  Joyce belongs to a village bank called God will provide. She hopes to receive GH¢500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more slippers and cooking oil, gari and fresh fish.

loans.name: Sosima Victoria,

texts.es:
Sosima ya lleva cinco años con su tienda de abarrotes, hace el mismo tiempo también que recibe los préstamos de EDAPROSPO. Anteriormente y por cuatro años, vendía verduras de ambulante en el mercado de Huaycán, pero se animó a empezar un negocio en un local, ya que estar por las calles todos los días ya se estaba convirtiendo muy peligroso para ella.
Aunque es soltera, Sosima junta sus ganancias con su pareja para cubrir los gastos del hogar, invertir en su negocio, y pagar los estudios de sus cinco hijos, una de los cuales todavía es menor de edad y vive con sus padres.
A sus cuarenta y ocho años ella espera poder, tras el cumplimiento de los estudios de todos sus hijos, seguir invirtiendo para agrandar su tienda y manejar un negocio más estable.
texts.en:
Sosima has had her grocery store for five years, the same length of time she has been receiving loans from EDAPROSPO. Before that, for four years, she sold vegetables walking through the market of Huaycán, but she decided to open a business in a fixed location because it was becoming too dangerous for her to continue being in the streets all day. Although unmarried, Sosima combines her profits with her partner to pay the household expenses, invest in her business, and pay for the studies of her five children, one of whom is still a minor and lives with her parents. At 48 years of age, she hopes to be able, because all her children will have completed their studies, to continue investing to expand her store and manage a more stable business.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She invested in merchandise for her store, mainly in beer.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es: Isabel a sus 43 años, es una madre de familia muy preocupada por el bienestar de su hogar, vive en su propia casa con sus 3 hijos; Edith de 14, Cristian de 12 y Kelly de 8 años, a los que quiere dar una buena educación y una mejor vida. Su negocio es la fabricación de adornos, como perlitas de fantasía, lentejuelas, etc, vende sus adornos a bordadores y artesanos, a los cuales les da un muy buen precio por su trabajo. Isabel  gusta de vender sus adornos y más aun si acaba toda su mercadería, lo cual pasa con frecuencia. Lo difícil es trasladar sus adornos hasta los lugares donde los tiene que vender, ya que le es muy cansado y el transporte le sale muy caro. Ya tiene 4 años en este negocio y espera incrementar la cantidad de adornitos que fabrica, porque es conciente que solo así podrá incrementar su economía y darles una mejor educación a sus hijos. Isabel se encuentra en su segundo préstamo con MFP, y está dispuesta a pagarlo por completo, para acceder a uno nuevo, confía plenamente en las socias de su banco comunal, en donde es muy querida. Con el dinero solicitado comprará más materiales para fabricar sus adornos y así incrementar sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Isabel is a 43-year-old mother who is very concerned about the well-being of her family. She has three children named Edith, Cristian and Kelly, aged 14, 12 and 8. She would like to afford them a good education and a better life.

Isabel has a handicraft business; she makes decorations out of beads, sequins, etc. She sells her decorations to seamstresses and artisans who give her a good price for her work. Isabel enjoys selling her decorations, especially when all her merchandise sells out – something that happens frequently. The difficulty is transferring her material to all the places she needs to sell, because it's tiring and transportation is expensive.

She's had this business for 4 years and hopes to increase the amount of decorations she crafts as she is conscious of the fact that increasing her income is the only way to give her children a better education.

This is Isabel's second loan with MFP and she's prepared to pay it back in full. Isabel is well-loved by the associates of the Communal Bank and counts on their support. With this loan, she will buy more material to make her decorations and as such increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy material for her handicrafts

loans.name: Vali

texts.en:
J. Vali is 74 years old. He’s married and has six children and several wonderful grandchildren. Vali is a farmer. He grows various crops like potatoes, carrots and wheat. His youngest son helps him with the business. Having been working on that business for more than 20 years, Vali has gained rich experience. Though he’s at retirement age, he’s not going to stop with the business as he is a diligent man and he can’t imagine his life without work.

Now Vali requests $1000 US Dollars for purchasing the input materials like seed and mineral fertilizer for growing his crops. After gathering his harvest he wants to sell them to the local inhabitants at lower prices than in the market. Vali promises to be accurate with repaying the loan and thanks everyone for support.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after Tajikistan’s independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Sharifmo

texts.en:
D. Sharifmo is a hard worker and a person that takes charge. She is married and has three children. Her husband receives a very low wage and they could not handle all the expenses of their family. For that reason, she saw it necessary to also enter the family business. Sharifmo began to sell foodstuff in her grocery store. This has been a fundamental piece in the growth of the business and, together, they have managed to advance it.

At this moment Sharifmo is asking for a loan of $1000 that she will use in the extension of her business to be able to offer a better service to her clients and to improve the aspect of her store. She promises to repay this amount in 12 months. Sharifmo says thanks very much for the aid and the confidence that you show in her.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To extend her business and improve her store

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda J. makes a living selling beans and charcoal at the local market, and is applying for this loan to open her own shop. She is 30 years old and married to a soldier.They have three children, all of whom are in primary school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy additional equipment for her business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to open up a shop

loans.name: Gladis

texts.es:
La socia es la Sra. Gladis, ella es natural del Cusco y vive en el distrito de San Sebastián.

Nuestra socia tiene 41 años de edad, ella es casada y tiene 3 hijos de (20,16,11) años, ella alterna sus labores del hogar con la atención casi a tiempo completo de su Panadería, por lo que ella solicita el préstamo para poder invertir en la compra de insumos, tales como harina, levadura, leña y otros más.

Nuestra socia se muestra muy agradecida y feliz por el préstamo otorgado y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago total de su deuda en el plazo determinado.
texts.en:
Gladis is a native of Cusco, and she lives in the San Sebastián district. She is 41 and married. She has three children ages 20, 16, and 11. She alternates between her house work and her almost full time attention to her bakery. She is asking for a loan to buy bakery supplies such as flour, leavening, and wood, among others. She is grateful and happy to have this means to borrow funds, and she commits to complete repayment of the loan in the agreed-upon time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for her bakery

loans.name: Jesselyn

texts.en:
Jesselyn N. is 27 years old, married and has four school-age children.They are from the village of Mamanga Daku. To make a living, Jesselyn raises pigs to sell. Jesselyn is just starting this business.

In 2006, Jesselyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Jesselyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Jesselyn is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This will be her fifth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase new tools, including a sander and a machine to make moldings

loans.name: Safinah's Group

texts.en:
S. Safinah is the leader of Bisoboka group in Lugazi. She is a married lady with 4 children aged 30 – 24, and one of them is still in school while she also cares for other orphans.

Safinah is a farmer with mostly maize and beans plantations and her major challenge is the dry season. Otherwise, she always has good produce which brings in good revenue. She has a business experience of 20 years and she is happy that she has enough land to carry out the farming.

Safinah has a dream of building a family house as well as increasing her production by buying more land for cultivation. She is a determined and friendly lady with a drive to succeed. Safinah needs a loan to help buy some beans and maize for resale since the dry season is affecting her farms somehow. (The Credit Officer recorded a video instead of taking a photo.)

loans.use: Buying produce for resale

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a member of the Kinanambo borrower group in Kinyanambo,Iringa,she is 40 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 5 children.Her children are aged 22,20,18,15,12 years.

Judith started her own Tailoring business 3 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Judith`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more material for her business.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan Judith hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Belgica Maritza

texts.es:
La señora Bélgica es socia del Banco Comunal Nueva Generación, un grupo relativamente nuevo que se reúne cada dos semanas en el Barrio Cuba en la ciudad de Manta, Provincia de Manabí, en la costa ecuatoriana.

Bélgica tiene 26 años y vive en unión libre con su pareja y su hijo de 2.5 años. Ella se dedica a la venta de sábanas, cortinas, y medicina natural. Su mamá le trae las cortinas y sábanas desde la ciudad de Guayaquil, y la medicina natural es de un catálogo. 

Vende de casa en casa, y también viaja fuera de la ciudad de Manta para vender sus productos. Sus clientas son generalmente sus amigas y antiguas compañeras de trabajo. Se dedica a esta actividad desde los 22 años y,  dice que aunque las ventas siempre suben y bajan le va bastante bien, y vende $30-$40 de mercadería cada semana. Le gusta su trabajo. 

Actualmente está pidiendo un crédito para comprar sábanas y cortinas con nuevos diseños y colores de moda e incrementar su stock de medicina natural.  No invertirá todo el crédito en la compra, sino que lo invertirá poco a poco de acuerdo a sus necesidades.

 Su meta para el futuro es poner una tienda en su casa, con vitrinas y todo. Lleva 2 ciclos trabajando con su banco comunal, y dice que es “una gran oportunidad que le brindan” porque los intereses son bajos y los pagos quincenales le convienen.
texts.en:
Bélgica is a member of the “Nueva Generación” communal bank, a relatively new group that meets every two weeks in the Cuba neighborhood in the city of Manta, in the province of Manabí, on the coast of Ecuador. Bélgica is 26 years old and lives with her common-law husband and her 2.5 year-old son. She sells sheets, curtains, and natural medicine. Her mother brings her the curtains and sheets from the city of Guayaquil, and the natural medicine is from a catalog. She sells door-to-door and she also travels outside the city of Manta to sell her products. Her customers are usually her friends and her acquaintances from her old job. She has been working in this business since she was 22 years old. She says that though sales always rise and fall, things are going very well and she sells $30 to $40 of merchandise per week. She likes her work. She is requesting a loan in order to buy sheets and curtains with new designs and fashionable colors and to increase her stock of natural medicines. She won’t invest all of her loan at once in purchases; rather she will spend it bit by bit as needed. Her goal for the future is to open a store in her house, with vitrines and all. She has been with the communal bank for two loan cycles, and she says it’s “a great opportunity being provided” because the interest is low and the twice-monthly payments work well for her.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheets and curtains in fashionable colors and designs and to increase her stock of natural medicine products

loans.name: Luis Manuel

texts.es: Luis Manuel es soltero,  vive en la zona # 4 en Nueva Guinea, trabaja como cajero del PALI de esta ciudad desde hace 2 años, esta solicitando su primer  crédito a AFODENIC para inventirlo  en la construccion de un cuarto en la casa de su mamá que es donde habita, y de esta manera poder tener mayor comodidad y privacidad, en su comunidad es conocido como un joven responsable, trabajador  que a pesar que no tiene hijos ayuda a su mamà con los gastos familiares,en su centro de trabajo y su barrio es  muy querido  por ser una persona de buen vivir y muy alegre, su sueño es seguir estudiando y que su familia siempre permanezca unida.
texts.en:
Luis Manuel is unmarried and lives in Zone 4 in Nueva Guinea (New Guinea), Nicaragua. He has been working as a cashier in his town’s PALI (supermarket chain) for 2 years. He is asking for his first loan from AFODENIC to invest in the construction of a room in his mother’s house where he lives so that he can be more comfortable and have greater privacy. He is known as a responsible young man in his community. Despite not having any children, he works to help his mother with the household expenses. Both in his place of work and his neighbourhood he is treasured as a lively and happy person. His dream is to continue his studies and that his family will always stay together.

Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a room in his mother's house

loans.name: One Business Group

texts.en:
One Business is group of four borrowers led by Patricia S.. She is a 28-year-old high school graduate and a single mother of a 6-year-old child who attends kindergarten. She lives in Waterside, a commercial area of downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Patricia's business is clothing.She buys clothes wholesale and sells at retail to the residents of downtown Monrovia, Liberia.
She started this business with LD $5000.00 and has been running her business for eight years. She hopes to expand her business to a bigger store.
Patricia sells quality products and gives her customers a better approach to encourage them to always come to patronize her business.
She needs a loan in order to purchase more quality goods to expand her business.
Patricia dreams of giving her children a better education and good health care.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy D. is from the village of Sabacan Panadtalan, Maramag Bukidnon. She is 44 years old. Daisy is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Daisy owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, where she sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Daisy has been in business for more than four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Daisy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daisy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP ,which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Daisy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Can Wange Pe Akello Margaret Group

texts.en:
A. Margaret is 39 years old and blessed with four children, all of whom are in school. She also looks after three dependents, who are also schooling.

Margaret deals in produce such as beans and groundnuts. She is requesting a loan to purchase more produce in order to increase her stock. She wishes to purchase six bags of each produce (beans, groundnuts, etc.). Margaret is an active businesswoman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more produce (beans, groundnuts, etc.) in order to increase her stock

loans.name: Philo

texts.en: Philo is 28 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a commercial motorcyclist. She is a hair stylist and she also sells hair extensions at retail prices to her customers. She is happy because the high season is here and her sales will increase. Philo lives in Edo State, Nigeria and is hoping for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions to sell to her customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia T. is from the village of Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 57 years old. Emilia is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Emilia owns and operates a business venture in the services sector, operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing transportation services to local community members. Emilia has been engaged in her motorcycle business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Wilberforce Osonyo

texts.en: Wilberforce Osonyo M. is a 37-year-old man, married and blessed with 3 children. He runs his own farm from which he supplies crops to the local market at Malanga, Busia district. Wilberforce started farming at around 15 years of age. He admits he was never good at books but in farming he is an A student. He would like a loan of Kshs. 30,000 to buy seedliings, fertilizer and hire labour for the new farm extension he made in preparation for the next rains.

loans.use: Buy seedlings, fertilizer, and hire labour

loans.name: Hin

texts.en:
This photo presents Mrs. Hin S., a woman who subsists on a low-income. She lives in Kampong Chhnang province. Hin is a widowed mother who is blessed with one daughter. The daughter has completed secondary school and presently works in the garment industry. Hin farms a rice crop to earn a living.

Recently Hin decided that she could earn more money from investing in a new enterprise. She has asked for a loan to use as capital to order mature rice from other farmers, which she will then sell to raise revenue.

loans.use: To order mature rice to sell.

loans.name: Dewompele #3 Group

texts.en: Kumba P. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Dewompele #3. She is 38 years old and is married with four children aged 10 to 24 years with educational level of 5th grade through university freshman student. She also cares for a grandchild. Kumba and her family lives in West Point, a very crowded and poor community close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She could not continue her education after 8th grade due to her developing eye problem. Kumba’s business is the sale of cosmetics for children. She buys her stock from wholesalers and sells retail in the Waterside market in downtown Monrovia. She has been running this business for six years and is hoping to own a cosmetics store in the near future. She talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Kumba started by selling underwear and her capital was 700 Liberian dollars. She then raised money to get into children’s cosmetics sales. She needs this loan to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She dreams of giving her children a better education and helping them to establish themselves. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kumba P. is the one holding the sign. Siah A. is inset at lower right. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: George Group

texts.en:
James K. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called George Group. He is 58 years old, married, and has three children who are 14, 24, and 26 years old.

For over 30 years James has had a tailoring business at the Happy Corner Market. His parents gave him his first machine. James says that he always tries to satisfy his customers and his clothes are good quality, which helps his business.

James plans to use his portion of the group loan to buy more clothes to sell. His goal is to have a big personal tailor shop and to help his children in every way possible.

In the photo James is holding the sign. Alice B. is in the inset at lower right.

About LEAP

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: María Irene

texts.es: María Irene C. D. P. D. 52 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. La Paz. Vive junto a su esposo y dos nietos D. 17 y 15 años D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar gracias al extraordinario trabajo y esfuerzo D. sus abuelos. La señora María se dedica a la compra D. cerdos D. granja, los cuales alimenta y cría para posteriormente vender o destazar para vender la carne. Así mismo se encarga D. procesar leche D. vaca la cual posteriormente sale a vender por las calles del departamento D. La Paz. DesD. hace 5 años que María tuvo la iniciativa D. emprender su propio negocio el cual le permitiera obtener ganancias extras y poder mejorar la estabilidad económica D. su familia. Es por esta razón que decidió utilizar el espacio con el que cuenta en el patio D. su casa y poner una pequeña granja D. cerdos. María solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. comida para cerdo, así mismo comprar más cerdos, los cuales pueda criar D. la mejor manera para luego vender a sus clientes. María posee una gran necesidad D. las ganancias D. este negocio, es por ello que cuenta con el deseo D. poder mejorarlo y seguir adelante con este.
texts.en:
María Irene C. D. P., 52, lives in La Paz department with her husband and two grandsons, who are 17 and 15 years of age; they can focus on being students thanks to the extraordinary efforts of their grandparents. María raises domestic pigs that she later either sells or butchers to sell the meat. She also processes cow's milk that she peddles along La Paz department's streets. It was five years ago that María took the initiative to start her own business that would make it possible for her to have extra income and be able to improve her family's economic stability. For this reason, she decided to use the space available in her yard to set up a small pig farm. María is asking for funding to buy more pig feed as well as more pigs to raise for subsequent sale to her customers. María's need for the profits from these sales is great, thus her desire to improve them and get ahead in life through them.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs and pig feed.

loans.name: Maria Felipa

texts.es:
La señora MARIA FELIPA D. J. tiene 56 años, vive en la provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal LA PERBOLA II. La socia  presenta estudios superiores hasta 6to de Primaria refiere que sus padres no le facilitaron mas educación porque no tenían recursos económicos, está casada, tiene 6 hijos de los cuales 1 depende económicamente de ella. La socia  se dedica a la confección  de peluches y mochilas para niños. Para la confección de los peluches y mochilas ella utiliza insumos como: peluche, tela polar, algodón industrial hilos, blondas, etc. y compra estos productos al por mayor en  el mercado mayorista porque los obtiene a menor costo lo cual le favorece, sus productos los vende en forma ambulatoria.
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles compró material como: tela de peluche, algodón, felpa, cierre, hilos, agujas, lana, etc. 
Con este crédito de  1,000.00 comprará mas material como: telas de algodón , telas de felpa , telas de polar, relleno de algodón , cierre, etc. para que haga mochilas para los niños de Inicial y de Primaria.
Ella sueña con aumentar sus ventas, sus ganancias y poder alquilar un puesto en un mercado o centro comercial en donde exhibir sus mochilas y muñecos para así poder generar mayores ventas e ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
María Felipa D. J. is 56, and she lives in the Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She belongs to the La Perbola II Communal Bank. She went to school until the sixth grade. Her parents did not have the economic resources to give her more education. She has six children, and one is economically dependent upon her. She makes stuffed animals and backpacks for children. To make the stuffed animals and backpacks she uses supplies like felt, polar fleece, industrial cotton thread, and silk lace, etc. She buys these products in the wholesale market because she gets them at a favorable lower cost. She sells her products as a traveling vendor. With her first loan for 300 PEN she bought material like fabric for stuffed animals, cotton, felt, zippers, thread, pins, and wool, etc. With this loan for 1,000 PEN she will buy more material like cotton fabric, felt, polar fleece, cotton filling, and zippers to make backpacks for children in primary and secondary school. She dreams of increasing her sales and her earnings and being able to rent a stand in the market or the commercial center where they display backpacks and stuffed animals. That way she would be able to generate greater sales and income for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy material like fabric for stuffed animals, cotton, felt, zippers, thread, pins, and wool, etc.

loans.name: Kantossowe

texts.en: Kantossowe D. is 59 years old, has one child, and is a widow. She lives in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo, and works from home. She makes and sells a local beverage called tchoukoutou (a local beer) and has been in this business since 1975. This will be her first loan with WAGES, which she will use to purchase necessary items to make this beverage – namely, a grain called sorgho and firewood. These items will allow Mrs. D. to augment her supply of tchoukoutou and keep her customers satisfied.

loans.use: Purchase of incredients to prepare and sell local beverage

loans.name: Rosita Yasely

texts.es:
Rosita tiene 24 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a sus padres en el caserío Insculas, una zona rural del distrito de Olmos, ubicado en la provincia de Lambayeque, a dos horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace un año a la venta de prendas de vestir, ella adquiere su mercadería con frecuencia en la ciudad de Chiclayo y la comercializa entre sus vecinos, este negocio tiene acogida en la zona ya que queda alejada de la ciudad de Chiclayo y no tienen acceso a prendas de vestir baratas. Rosita nos comenta que inició el negocio llevada por la necesidad de obtener una fuente permanente de ingresos que le permita solventar sus gastos personales y apoyar a la economía de su familia.

El negocio goza de buena acogida entre los vecinos de la zona y ella piensa ampliarlo, por ello se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de más ropa para ofrecérsela a sus clientes.

Rosita es una joven trabajadora y responsable, su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresaria para poder percibir mas ingresos y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida, sus vecinos y conocidos la consideran una mujer de confianza.
texts.en:
Rosita, 24, is single and lives with her parents in Insculas, a rural area of Olmos, Lambayeque province, which is two hours away from the city of Chiclayo. She has sold clothing for the last year; she buys her merchandise frequently in Chiclayo and sells to her neighbors. Her business has been well-received because the area is far from the city of Chiclayo and they don’t have easy access to low cost clothing. Rosita tells us that she started the business because she needed to have a permanent source of income in order to meet her personal expenses and contribute to her family’s support. Her business is well-received among her neighbors in the area and she plans to expand it. This has led her to approach Edpyme Alternativa for the first time to request a 1000 new sol loan to buy more stock merchandise. Rosita is a hard-working, responsible young woman; her greatest wish is to continue to grow as a businesswoman in order to earn higher income and provide her family with improved quality of life. Her neighbors and acquaintances consider her trustworthy.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy articles of clothing.

loans.name: Ñamba'apo Hagua(Para Trabajar) Group

texts.es:
El comité “Ñamba'apo hagua” (para trabajar) está conformada por 18 integrantes, en la ciudad de Mariano Roque Alonso. 
Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas, empleada Doméstica.
 Las integrantes participan puntualmente en las reuniones semanales  y en la Capacitaciones, demostraron interés con respecto al Programa Comité de Mujeres y todos los programas de la Fundación Paraguaya.
Todas las integrantes del comité son madres que se dedican a varias actividades con el fin de fortalecer la economía de la casa y desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera sustentable y con vistas a un crecimiento constante, con la ayuda de una asistencia financiera permanente.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Blanca quien se dedica a la venta de mercaderías varias, tales como enlatados, alimentos no perecederos, golosinas, bebidas, descartables, etc. distribuidos al detalle a los consumidores en general y tambien a pequeñas tiendas dedicadas al ramo.
Su intención principal es la ampliación del ramo de su negocio, procurando implementar otros medios de distribución como serían pequeños carritos, para facilitar la entrega de mercaderías a los clientes, todo teniendo en cuenta la demanda que posee gracias a la buena clientela ya formada.
texts.en:
The group “Ñamba'apo hagua” (“To Work”), comprised of 18 members, is in the city of Mariano Roque Alonso. All the members of this group carry out their own activities, which include working as merchants and maids. The members are punctual about attending their weekly meetings, and demonstrated interest in the Women’s Programs and all the programs of Fundación Paraguaya. All the members are mothers who carry out various activities in order to contribute to the financial stability of their households. They have hopes of growing their businesses in a sustainable manner, and want to see continued growth along with the assistance of permanent financial support. One of the members is Blanca, who dedicates herself to selling various types of products such as canned goods, non-perishables, snacks, beverages, etc. She distributes her merchandise both directly to the consumer, as well as to small stores that also sell these types of goods. Her primary goal is to expand her business and finding other means of distributing her merchandise by other means, such as small carts, so that she can sell to a greater number of customers. She makes all her plans based on the demand she has thanks to the good customer base she has established.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy large quantities of beverages, canned goods, bread products, etc.

loans.name: Renel

texts.en:
Renel S. is from the village of Palutan. He is 40 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Renel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting corn for sale. Renel has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 55,000 PHP during harvest season.
In 2009, Renel joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Renel is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be his third from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
